item.title: DTV Transition For Wireless Mic Users
item.description:
The U.S. is in the middle of transitioning to digital television, a process that began on February 17th and will continue until June 12th. This shift brings significant changes for many wireless microphone users, potentially disrupting their ability to operate. The transition, often called the DTV transition, signifies a complete reallocation of VHF and UHF frequencies that have been used for over-the-air television broadcasting for the past five decades. While the main goal is to switch from analog to digital broadcasting, the implications extend far beyond this...

item.title: White Spaces Debate Outs Wireless Mics
item.description:
An unexpected result of the debate about the “white space” TV spectrum is the exposure of unauthorized wireless microphone users like churches, theaters, and conference rooms. Many have been using unused UHF TV channels undetected for years. They must now cease or face interference from the new owners of the 700 MHz spectrum when those services begin next February. Finding new channels by simply re-tuning is becoming less feasible. Wireless microphones have become increasingly common in any situation involving vocal performance, from televised concerts to news shows and Broadway plays...
